image.altText: Rear and side of a Victoria Police divisional van. Taken March 2023

image.altText: A man's face hidden by a puffer jacket hood.

image.altText: People stand over a map of the world.

title.children: This is what the average human day looks like. How do Australians compare?

image.altText: A woman making a coffee in a cafe

image.altText: A Golden Globe award, shaped like a globe on a pedestal with a strip of movie film wrapped around it.

image.altText: A composite image of three people on stage wearing long gowns

image.altText: First-term Labor MP Michelle Ananda-Rajah sits in parliament.

items.synopsis: A Victorian government plan to reduce the state's brumby population through rehoming has approved only 11 applications, while dozens of trapped horses have been released because they don't fit preferences.

title.children: Trapped brumbies set free as feral horse control program struggles to find homes

image.altText: A close up shot of a man wearing glasses and a baseball cap

items.synopsis: The 23-year-old man accused of running down Perth police officer Anthony Woods faces court as the charge against him is upgraded to murder.

title.children: Man who allegedly mowed down police officer faces murder charge in Perth court

image.altText: A Denver NBA player smiles and puts his hands on his head in celebration after his team wins a title.

image.altText: Four Guatemalan women looking at a laptop screen.

items.synopsis: The world is unlikely to meet the UN's goal of gender parity by 2030, new research finds.

title.children: Bias against women is the same as it was a decade ago, says UN

image.altText: A man with a small moustache and dressed in camo sits inside a military vehicle

items.synopsis: As Ukrainian forces continue their push in and around Bakhmut, soldiers returned from the frontline say the Australian-built armoured personnel carrier is helping keep them alive.

title.children: 'If the Australians were around, I would hug them': Ukraine's soldiers thrilled with Bushmaster performance on battlefield

image.altText: Ukrainian service members of the 55th Separate Artillery Brigade fire a Caesar self-propelled howitzer towards Russian troops.

items.synopsis: Ukraine says troops recaptured seven villages from Russian forces in the south-east, as France promises more military aid to Kyiv to help with its counteroffensive.

title.children: 'The enemy's losses are exactly what we need': Zelenskyy claims counteroffensive making progress

image.altText: A close-up of a red fire ant nest.

items.synopsis: The red fire ant, which can be lethal to humans and animals, has been found on the western side of the Great Dividing Range for the first time.

title.children: Dangerous pest that could be 'worse' than the cane toad breaches containment zone

image.altText: A large dam spilling water over its edge.

items.synopsis: The state government will spend a total of $1 billion increasing the capacity of a north Queensland dam by 150,000 megalitres.

title.children: $500m allocated to upgrade Queensland's largest dam as cost blowout revealed

image.altText: A composite image of a bald PNG man with glasses wearing a grey suit and another PNG man wearing a grey cap

items.synopsis: Despite having to flee his home, Neville Devete says he has no regrets after sparking Papua New Guinea's biggest corruption investigation.

title.children: 'It was plainly corrupt': The man who helped take down one of PNG's biggest fraudsters

image.altText: A man holding a high-tech space cube.

items.synopsis: Space junk is made of hundreds of millions of fragments orbiting Earth — and while it isn't a giant space bin, a small high-tech cube could be used to help hoover up some of the debris.

title.children: Does this box contain the answer to the problem of space junk?

image.altText: A drone shot of rows of houses in Shell Cove, Wollongong's south.

items.synopsis: The value of Australian homes rebounds to $9.9 trillion, but higher interest rates means consumers are more wary of getting into the property market. And the ASX turns higher after US stocks reach a 13-month high.

title.children: Home prices rise but consumers think it's a bad time to buy a house, ASX reverses course

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Nickel and lithium producer IGO has appointed Ivan Vella as its new chief executive. Mr Vella runs Rio Tinto's aluminium division and will take up his new job in December. He has been with Rio Tinto for 20 years, and was brought in to run the iron ore division after the company destroyed sacred Aboriginal caves at Juukan Gorge in the Pilbara in Western Australia in 2020. Mr Vella will replace IGO's former chief executive Peter Bradford, who died last October. IGO owns nickel, copper and cobalt mines in Western Australia, and in partnership with Tianqi Lithium Corporation, a lithium mine and refining plant.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rio aluminium boss to run battery minerals producer

children.content: Nickel and lithium producer IGO has appointed Ivan Vella as its new chief executive.
Mr Vella runs Rio Tinto's aluminium division and will take up his new job in December.

He has been with Rio Tinto for 20 years, and was brought in to run the iron ore division after the company destroyed sacred Aboriginal caves at Juukan Gorge in the Pilbara in Western Australia in 2020.
Mr Vella will replace IGO's former chief executive Peter Bradford, who died last October.
IGO owns nickel, copper and cobalt mines in Western Australia, and in partnership with Tianqi Lithium Corporation, a lithium mine and refining plant.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Retail giant Wesfarmers has moved further into healthcare by buying online prescription and telehealth firm InstantScripts. Wesfarmer's subsidiary Australian Pharmaceutical Industries will buy InstantScripts from Bailador Technology Investments for $135 million. Wesfarmers Health managing director, Emily Amos, said InstantScripts will become part of her division. “Over recent years telehealth has emerged as an important service, complementing the care delivered through GP practices, pharmacies and other allied health providers,” Ms Amos said. "InstantScripts provides flexible services that are available at short notice and outside of normal consultation hours, and is accessible to patients in remote areas and those who have difficulty visiting a GP."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wesfarmers buys InstantScripts

children.content: Retail giant Wesfarmers has moved further into healthcare by buying online prescription and telehealth firm InstantScripts.
Wesfarmer's subsidiary Australian Pharmaceutical Industries will buy InstantScripts from Bailador Technology Investments for $135 million.
Wesfarmers Health managing director, Emily Amos, said InstantScripts will become part of her division.
“Over recent years telehealth has emerged as an important service, complementing the care
delivered through GP practices, pharmacies and other allied health providers,” Ms Amos said.
"InstantScripts provides flexible services that are available at
short notice and outside of normal consultation hours, and is accessible to patients in remote
areas and those who have difficulty visiting a GP."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Westpac says the combination of higher interest rates and higher home prices is driving a sharp fall in home buyer sentiment according to its latest consumer confidence survey. The 'time to buy a dwelling index' fell 5.7 per cent to 72, near historical lows. Westpac chief economist Bill Evans: "While these are not the weakest index reads on record, the sixteen month run since March is easily the most prolonged period of very weak buyer sentiment we have seen since the survey began in 1974," he said. However, he noted people still expect home prices to rise over the next year despite last week's rate hike. "Despite the unexpected increase in the cash rate, expectations for house prices remained firmly positive," he said. "Over 60 per cent of consumers expect prices to rise over the next 12 months."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Not the time to buy but home prices expected to keep rising

children.content: Westpac says the combination of higher interest rates and higher home prices is driving a sharp fall in home buyer sentiment according to its latest consumer confidence survey.
The 'time to buy a dwelling index' fell 5.7 per cent to 72, near historical lows.
Westpac chief economist Bill Evans:

"While these are not the weakest index reads on record, the sixteen month run since March is easily the most prolonged period of very weak buyer sentiment we have seen since the survey began in 1974," he said.
However, he noted people still expect home prices to rise over the next year despite last week's rate hike.
"Despite the unexpected increase in the cash rate, expectations for house prices remained firmly positive," he said.
"Over 60 per cent of consumers expect prices to rise over the next 12 months."

image.altText: Former president Donald Trump walks up stairs to board a large aircraft with TRUMP written on the side in gold letters.

items.synopsis: Supporters gather outside a Miami golf club the former president owns, while Mr Trump calls for a planned protest outside the courthouse where he is due to face charges and surrender to authorities.

title.children: Donald Trump arrives in Florida to face charges in documents case

image.altText: A statue of Lady Justice at Old Bailey central criminal court in London.

items.synopsis: A 44-year-old mother of three has been sentenced to more than two years in an English prison for medically inducing an abortion about eight months into her pregnancy.

title.children: Mother in England jailed for 28 months after medicated abortion later in pregnancy

image.altText: An orange, white and black F1 car is driving down a straight, heading towards the camera, with the driver visible.

image.altText: Woman with grey hair and glasses listens to colleagues at a meeting

items.synopsis: Generational stereotypes can sound convincing, but in the workplace they can become a pervasive form of ageism.

title.children: Entitled, cynical or narcissistic: The generational stereotypes causing harm at work

image.altText: 38-year-old athletic man, bare-chested and with shoulder and arm tatts, looks at camera with smile. Someone is holding his torso

items.synopsis: The South Australian artist grew up thinking his body — and sexuality — was wrong. In his new show, he moves past shame into pride and power.

title.children: Dan Daw's show comes with a warning – you'll see kink, and 'sexy disabled people'
